column4: Yields on 10-year JGBs unchanged on year-end thin trade
column5: TOKYO, March 26 (Reuters) - Japan’s benchmark 10-year government bond yields were flat on Friday, in thin trade ahead of the fiscal year close this month, while U.S. Treasury yields stabilising after sharp gains capped investor appetite.
column6: The 10-year JGB yield was flat at 0.080% and the 20-year JGB yield was also unchanged at 0.455%.
column7: The 30-year JGB yield rose two basis points to 0.650%, the five-year yield fell 0.5 basis point to minus 0.105%.
column8: The 40-year JGB yield rose two basis points to 0.690%.
column9: Benchmark 10-year JGB futures rose 0.02 point to 151.36, with a trading volume of 11,348 lots. (Reporting by Tokyo markets team; Editing by Rashmi Aich)

column4: Auction of seven-year Treasury notes better, but still on weak side
column5: March 25 (Reuters) - The U.S. Treasury’s $62 billion auction of seven-year notes on Thursday outperformed last month’s dismal showing, but still showed signs of the market’s struggle to absorb the enormous amount of issuance in the belly of the maturity curve to finance pandemic relief.
column6: Weak demand last month for debt in that maturity accelerated a selloff in Treasuries and focused market attention on auctions this month.
column7: The notes were sold on Thursday at a high yield of 1.3% - 2.5 basis points above the market at the bidding deadline, “which is generally not a great sign and a pretty big tail,” according to Zachary Griffiths, macro strategist at Wells Fargo.
column8: Still, he noted that some of the other metrics “weren’t nearly as bad” and the seven-year yield was trading below the auction yield.
column9: The bid-to-cover ratio, a gauge of demand, was 2.23, up from February’s record-low 2.04 ratio. Direct bidders took 18% of the sale.
column10: It followed other auctions this week with $60 billion of two-year notes drawing solid demand on Tuesday and $61 billion of five-year notes performing slightly better than average on Wednesday.
column11: “This week of auctions in general probably calmed things down at the margin, but I think auctions will continue to be in focus going forward,” Griffiths said. “They will definitely be a gauge of where demand is as yields have risen, but supply is going to remain very heavy in the coupon sector this year.”

column4: UPDATE 1-U.S. blacklists two Myanmar military-controlled companies -U.S. Treasury
column5: The United States imposed sanctions on two more state-owned enterprises in Myanmar on Wednesday in the latest in a series of punitive actions following the country's military coup, and said it would take further action.
column6: The U.S. Treasury Department in a statement said it imposed sanctions on Myanma Timber Enterprise (MTE) and Myanmar Pearl Enterprise (MPE), adding that the pearl and timber industries are economic resources for the Myanmar military.
column7: The Southeast Asian country has been in crisis since the February coup when the military seized power from Aung San Suu Kyi's elected government, with almost daily protests and a crackdown by the junta in which hundreds of people have been killed.
column8: U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken said Washington would continue to target funding channels to the junta.
column9: "We will continue to support the people of Burma in their efforts to reject this coup, and we call on the military regime to cease violence, release all those unjustly detained, and restore Burma’s path to democracy," Blinken said in a separate statement.
column10: The Assistance Association for Political Prisoners (AAPP), an activist group, says 738 people have been killed by Myanmar's security forces since the coup and 3,300 people are in detention. Another 20 people have been sentenced to death and are in hiding.
column11: Wednesday's action freezes any U.S. assets of the businesses and generally bars Americans from dealing with the companies that the Treasury said are responsible for timber and pearl exports from Myanmar.
column12: The Environmental Investigation Agency, an international nonprofit that documents timber industry abuses in Myanmar and elsewhere, said this month that the military junta profits from the export of teak through MTE.
column13: That teak is sometimes exported to the United States and Europe and used for luxury furniture and for the decks of high-end yachts, the group says.
column14: "Sanctions placed on MTE in Myanmar is a significant blow to the military regime, which directly profits from the country’s valuable and diminishing forests," said Faith Doherty, the group's forests campaign leader.
column15: She added that the move, which means no timber or timber products from Myanmar can be exported to the United States, would also undermine corrupt officials.
column16: Advocacy groups Human Rights Now and Justice for Myanmar said Japanese jewelry firm Tasaki should end all business with MPE, accusing the pearl company of supporting the junta by maintaining business with the state-owned enterprise.
column17: Tasaki did not immediately respond to an emailed request for comment.

column4: GLOBAL MARKETS-Wall Street heads for steady open, Intel a bright spot
column5: Wall Street headed for a firmer open on Wednesday, with Intel a bright spot amid investor worry that global recovery from COVID-19 will be patchier as parts of Europe enter fresh lockdowns in a year-long pandemic.
column6: The dollar hit a four-month high, supported by a weaker appetite for shares in Asia and Europe. Yields eased and oil bounced.
column7: "We are definitely in that mode of a potential further reduction in risk, which would be supportive for the dollar," said Derek Halpenny, head of research for global markets at MUFG.
column8: "If you were to pick a top concern, then it would be the COVID situation, with new cases in emerging markets back to record highs and what's happening in Europe. It does not tally with global optimism for synchronised global growth," Halpenny added.
column9: U.S. stock futures pointed to a steadier start on Wall Street after Tuesday's tumble. Dow E-minis , S&P 500 E-minis and Nasdaq 100 E-minis advanced by 0.4% to 0.7%.
column10: Intel shares (INTC.O) jumped about 5.7% as the chipmaker announced plans to spend as much as $20 billion to build two factories in Arizona and open its factories to outside customers, sending shares in rivals higher. read more
column11: Bitcoin gained nearly 5% as Tesla Inc (TSLA.O) chief Elon Musk said the company's electric vehicles can now be bought using bitcoin. read more
column12: Wall Street will scrutinise IHS Markit's flash reading, which is likely to show business activity in the manufacturing and services sectors improved in March from the prior month.
column13: Benchmark 10-year U.S. Treasury notes last yielded 1.6278%, slightly lower after reaching 14-month highs last week.
column14: COVID'S ECONOMIC SHADOW
column15: European shares hit a two-week low before the pan-European STOXX (.STOXX) index of leading companies recovered some lost ground, down 0.19%. Travel stocks were among the biggest fallers on the prospect of holidays abroad remaining a dream for now.
column16: Paris (.FCHI), Frankfurt (.GDAXI) and London (.FTSE) were all weaker.
column17: "The mood is fairly fragile as all the optimism that characterised the push higher over the past two or three weeks in shares is starting to bleed away on talk of a European third wave and extensions of pandemic lockdowns in Germany and France," said Michael Hewson, chief market analyst at CMC Markets.
column18: The Ifo Institute said Germany's extended lockdown is delaying recovery. It cut its 2021 growth forecast for Europe's biggest economy to 3.7% from 4.2% previously.
column19: The IHS Markit euro zone flash composite purchasing management index rose to 52.5 in March from 48.8 in February in a surprise return to growth this month, as factories ramped up production at its fastest pace in over 23 years.
column20: But the April numbers could be hit by the gathering pace of COVID infections across Europe. read more
column21: Wall Street tumbled on Tuesday on concerns about the cost of infrastructure spending and potential tax hikes to pay for President Joe Biden's $1.9 trillion relief bill.
column22: Still, the S&P 500 index's (.SPX) 75% increase from March 2020 troughs represents the biggest rolling 12-month increase in the index since 1936, Deutsche Bank noted.
column23: U.S. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen said on Tuesday the U.S. economy remains in crisis from the pandemic as she defended developing plans for future tax increases to pay for the new public investments. read more
column24: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell told U.S. lawmakers that a coming round of post-pandemic price increases will not fuel a destructive breakout of persistent inflation. He meets with U.S. lawmakers again on Wednesday. read more
column25: Asian shares skidded to a two-week trough overnight and the dollar neared four-month highs.
column26: MSCI's broadest index of Asia-Pacific shares outside of Japan (.MIAPJ0000PUS) fell 1.1% to 675.81 points.
column27: In currencies, the dollar index hit a four-month high of 92.608 against a basket of most major currencies . The euro edged down 0.16% to $1.831.
column28: Oil bounced 2% from heavy losses overnight, helped by news of a ship running aground in the Suez Canal, though traffic was expected to resume soon.
column29: Brent crude futures rose 2.8% to $62.47 a barrel, after tumbling 5.9% to a low of $60.50 on Tuesday. West Texas Intermediate crude futures added 2.7% to $59.37, having lost 6.2% the previous day.
column30: Safe-haven gold was higher at $1,731.9 an ounce.

column4: GLOBAL MARKETS-Global stocks ease as lockdowns sap momentum, oil rebounds
column5: Global shares eased on Wednesday as optimism over the pace of recovery from COVID-19 that propelled markets to record highs was fizzling out in the face of more lockdowns in continental Europe.
column6: European shares hit a two-week low before the pan-European STOXX (.STOXX) index of leading companies recovered some lost ground to trade down 0.18%. Travel stocks were among the biggest fallers on the prospect of holidays abroad remaining a dream for now.
column7: Paris (.FCHI) and Frankfurt (.GDAXI) were weaker, with London (.FTSE) edging up. U.S. stock futures pointed to a steadier start on Wall Street after Tuesday's tumble.
column8: "The mood is fairly fragile as all the optimism that characterised the push higher over the past two or three weeks in shares is starting to bleed away on talk of a European third wave and extensions of pandemic lockdowns in Germany and France," said Michael Hewson, chief market analyst at CMC Markets.
column9: The Ifo Institute said Germany's extended lockdown is delaying recovery, cutting its 2021 growth forecast for Europe's biggest economy to 3.7% from 4.2% previously.
column10: "Coming on top of EU threats to limit vaccine supplies, it has created a reassessment of the glide path to any recovery. It was a big ask to get a return to international travel as soon as markets were pricing in," Hewson said.
column11: The IHS Markit euro zone flash composite purchasing management index rose to 52.5 in March from 48.8 in February in a surprise return to growth this month, as factories ramped up production at its fastest pace in over 23 years.
column12: But the gathering pace of lockdowns in Europe and slow vaccine rollout could mean more subdued numbers in April, analysts said.
column13: A 2% bounce in oil after hefty losses overnight was capped by the prospect of lower fuel demand because of continued lockdowns, though analysts said the drop should ease upward pressure on bond yields and diminish the "inflation scare" in markets recently.
column14: "The rise in global yields observed over the past few months seems to have taken a break this week, as investors are probably awaiting new positive signals on the economic recovery," UniCredit bank said in a note to clients.
column15: Benchmark 10-year U.S. Treasury notes last yielded 1.6207% after reaching 14-month highs last week.
column16: Inflation expectations declined in Britain, where consumer price inflation unexpectedly fell to 0.4% in February amid discounts in clothing.
column17: TAX HIKES?
column18: Wall Street tumbled on Tuesday on concerns about the cost of infrastructure spending and potential tax hikes to pay for President Joe Biden's $1.9 trillion relief bill.
column19: Still, the S&P 500 index's (.SPX) 75% increase from March 2020 troughs represents the biggest rolling 12-month increase in the index since 1936, Deutsche Bank noted.
column20: U.S. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen said on Tuesday the U.S. economy remains in crisis from the pandemic as she defended developing plans for future tax increases to pay for the new public investments. read more
column21: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell told U.S. lawmakers that a coming round of post-pandemic price increases will not fuel a destructive breakout of persistent inflation. He meets with U.S. lawmakers again on Wednesday. read more
column22: U.S. manufacturing data was due later on Wednesday.
column23: Asian shares skidded to a two-week trough overnight and the dollar neared four-month highs.
column24: MSCI's broadest index of Asia-Pacific shares outside of Japan (.MIAPJ0000PUS) fell 1.1% to 675.81 points.
column25: In currencies, the dollar index hit a four-month high of 92.608 against a basket of most major currencies.
column26: The euro edged toward a four-month low below $1.1833 and traded as low as $1.1813.
column27: Brent crude futures rose 2% to $62.13 a barrel, after tumbling 5.9% to a low of $60.50 on Tuesday. West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude futures added 2% to $59, having lost 6.2% the previous day.
column28: Safe-haven gold was higher at $1,732.5 an ounce.

column4: Stocks slide as stimulus, infrastructure costs spook investors
column5: NEW YORK (Reuters) -U.S. stocks tumbled on Tuesday as concerns about the cost of infrastructure spending and potential tax hikes to pay for President Joe Biden’s $1.9 trillion relief bill weighed on investors who also fear further downside in the market.
column6: Remarks by Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen that the U.S. economy remains in crisis from the pandemic as she defended developing plans for future tax increases to pay for the new public investments put investors on alert.
column7: Yellen spoke at a hearing of the House Financial Services Committee where Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell also addressed the committee.
column8: Talk of the government’s infrastructure plans unnerved investors who are concerned the stock market is trading at elevated valuations, said Rick Meckler, partner at Cherry Lane Investments in New Vernon, New Jersey.
column9: “There’s a little bit of concern of getting out ahead of a potential selloff that could be on the horizon,” Meckler said. “Any feeling that it could be on the horizon is causing people to pull the trigger pretty quick on these down moves.”
column10: Stocks had been trading near break-even in seesaw trade before turning sharply lower about 45 minutes before the close.
column11: Powell told U.S. lawmakers that a coming round of post-pandemic price hikes will not fuel a destructive breakout of persistent inflation - fears that had sparked a recent rise in yields and caused technology shares to sell off.
column12: Oil prices that slumped more than 3% on worries that new pandemic curbs and slow vaccine rollouts in Europe will slow a recovery in demand helped push the energy sector lower. [O/R]
column13: Falling yields on 10-year U.S. Treasury notes from a 14-month highs last week have deflated this year’s outperformance in the financial and energy sectors.
column14: Conversely, technology-related shares that had recently declined sharply on the rising rate environment had recuperated a bit as yields eased, said Peter Tuz, president of Chase Investment Counsel in Charlottesville, Virginia.
column15: “A lot of these (tech) stocks have seen 10% to 20% corrections and interest rates have backed off a bit,” Tuz said. “The money seems to be going back into them and out of the groups that did extremely well the last three months, specifically financials and energy.”
column16: The benchmark S&P 500 and the blue-chip Dow have rallied about 80% from their pandemic lows of a year ago, while the tech-heavy Nasdaq more than doubled in value.
column17: Small cap stocks, which had outperformed this year, along with financials, energy and international stocks, fell 3.5% in the biggest single-day decline since Feb. 25.
column18: The CBOE volatility index eased to its lowest level in 13 months before jumping about 11% on the day. Wall Street’s so-called fear gauge still hovers near pandemic lows.
column19: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 308.05 points, or 0.94%, to 32,423.15 and the S&P 500 lost 30.07 points, or 0.76%, to 3,910.52. The Nasdaq Composite dropped 149.85 points, or 1.12%, to 13,227.70.
column20: Volume on U.S. exchanges was 12.10 billion shares, compared with the 14.04 billion average for the full session over the last 20 trading days.
column21: Shares of GameStop Corp dropped 6.5% ahead of the company’s fourth-quarter results due later on Tuesday. The videogame retailer announced the exit of its chief customer officer in the latest sign of a broader overhaul into an e-commerce firm.
column22: ViacomCBS Inc tumbled 9.1% after the media firm launched $3 billion stock deals to raise capital for investments in streaming.
column23: U.S.-listed shares of Chinese internet search provider Baidu Inc slid 1.7% following a flat Hong Kong debut as investors were wary of a fundraising flurry in the city and questioned the company’s growth plans.
column24: Declining issues outnumbered advancing ones on the NYSE by a 3.42-to-1 ratio; on Nasdaq, a 6.64-to-1 ratio favored decliners.
column25: The S&P 500 posted 11 new 52-week highs and no new lows; the Nasdaq Composite recorded 45 new highs and 99 new lows.

column4: US STOCKS-Stocks slide as stimulus, infrastructure costs spook investors
column5: U.S. stocks tumbled on Tuesday as concerns about the cost of infrastructure spending and potential tax hikes to pay for President Joe Biden's $1.9 trillion relief bill weighed on investors who also fear further downside in the market.
column6: Remarks by Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen that the U.S. economy remains in crisis from the pandemic as she defended developing plans for future tax increases to pay for the new public investments put investors on alert. read more
column7: Yellen spoke at a hearing of the House Financial Services Committee where Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell also addressed the committee.
column8: Talk of the government's infrastructure plans unnerved investors who are concerned the stock market is trading at elevated valuations, said Rick Meckler, partner at Cherry Lane Investments in New Vernon, New Jersey.
column9: "There's a little bit of concern of getting out ahead of a potential selloff that could be on the horizon," Meckler said. "Any feeling that it could be on the horizon is causing people to pull the trigger pretty quick on these down moves."
column10: Stocks had been trading near break-even in seesaw trade before turning sharply lower about 45 minutes before the close.
column11: Powell told U.S. lawmakers that a coming round of post-pandemic price hikes will not fuel a destructive breakout of persistent inflation - fears that had sparked a recent rise in yields and caused technology shares to sell off. read more
column12: Oil prices that slumped more than 3% on worries that new pandemic curbs and slow vaccine rollouts in Europe will slow a recovery in demand helped push the energy sector lower.
column13: Falling yields on 10-year U.S. Treasury notes from a 14-month highs last week have deflated this year's outperformance in the financial (.SPSY) and energy (.SPNY) sectors.
column14: Conversely, technology-related shares that had recently declined sharply on the rising rate environment had recuperated a bit as yields eased, said Peter Tuz, president of Chase Investment Counsel in Charlottesville, Virginia.
column15: "A lot of these (tech) stocks have seen 10% to 20% corrections and interest rates have backed off a bit," Tuz said. "The money seems to be going back into them and out of the groups that did extremely well the last three months, specifically financials and energy."
column16: The benchmark S&P 500 and the blue-chip Dow have rallied about 80% from their pandemic lows of a year ago, while the tech-heavy Nasdaq more than doubled in value.
column17: Small cap stocks (.RUT), which had outperformed this year, along with financials, energy and international stocks, fell 3.5% in the biggest single-day decline since Feb. 25.
column18: The CBOE volatility index (.VIX) eased to its lowest level in 13 months before jumping about 11% on the day. Wall Street's so-called fear gauge still hovers near pandemic lows.
column19: The Dow Jones Industrial Average (.DJI) fell 308.05 points, or 0.94%, to 32,423.15 and the S&P 500 (.SPX) lost 30.07 points, or 0.76%, to 3,910.52. The Nasdaq Composite (.IXIC) dropped 149.85 points, or 1.12%, to 13,227.70.
column20: Volume on U.S. exchanges was 12.10 billion shares, compared with the 14.04 billion average for the full session over the last 20 trading days.
column21: Shares of GameStop Corp (GME.N) dropped 6.5% ahead of the company's fourth-quarter results due later on Tuesday. The videogame retailer announced the exit of its chief customer officer in the latest sign of a broader overhaul into an e-commerce firm. read more
column22: ViacomCBS Inc tumbled 9.1% after the media firm launched $3 billion stock deals to raise capital for investments in streaming.
column23: U.S.-listed shares of Chinese internet search provider Baidu Inc (BIDU.O) slid 1.7% following a flat Hong Kong debut as investors were wary of a fundraising flurry in the city and questioned the company's growth plans. read more
column24: Declining issues outnumbered advancing ones on the NYSE by a 3.42-to-1 ratio; on Nasdaq, a 6.64-to-1 ratio favored decliners.
column25: The S&P 500 posted 11 new 52-week highs and no new lows; the Nasdaq Composite recorded 45 new highs and 99 new lows.

column4: Funds expect subdued U.S. inflation, strong EM FX - Russell Investments survey
column5: LONDON (Reuters) - Fixed income managers expect the U.S. Treasury yield curve to steepen in the next 12 months and many anticipate inflation will remain subdued in a 1.8-2.4% range, a survey from Russell Investments showed on Tuesday.
column6: Benchmark 10-year U.S. Treasury yields have risen over 70 basis points this year as investors bet on a strong economic recovery that will boost inflation. The U.S. Federal Reserve now targets an “average” of 2% inflation, instead of a fixed 2% goal, giving it more flexibility.
column7: According to the Russell survey conducted in February, 76% of respondents expect U.S. inflation to hover between the Federal Reserve’s target rate of 1.8-2.4%. Just 10% see a deflationary environment ahead, versus 21% in the previous quarter’s survey.
column8: Of the 50 bond and currency managers that responded to Russell’s first-quarter survey, 57% expected the global economy to recover to pre-pandemic levels in 2022.
column9: Bond and currency managers expected investment grade assets will offer the most attractive risk-adjusted returns in the next 12 months, favouring high-yield assets and emerging market local and hard currency debt.
column10: The survey revealed a preference among money managers for the Brazilian real as the most attractive emerging market currency in the next 12 months. Almost 89% expected a positive performance from emerging market currencies.
column11: The real has lost around 6% so far this year against the dollar, underperforming broader emerging currencies though they too are down 0.7% year-to-date.
column12: Russell said 71% of managers expect emerging market FX implied volatility to rise in the next 12 months compared to 57% who predicted higher implied volatility for major currencies.
column13: Investors appear to have become less bullish on the euro, which 61% of managers saw in a $1.21-$1.25 range. Russell’s fourth-quarter 2020 survey showed 73% believed the single currency would trade between $1.21 and $1.30.
column14: The euro was near $1.19 on Tuesday.

column4: U.S. Treasury auctions to test demand after volatile trading
column5: CHICAGO (Reuters) - Demand for U.S. Treasuries will be tested this week as $183 billion of notes are due to be auctioned, with one seven-year note sale likely to be closely watched after an auction of that maturity stumbled last month.
column6: The U.S. Treasury Department has increased debt issuance dramatically in the last year to finance stimulus measures to combat economic fallout from the coronavirus pandemic. Issuance in 2021 is slated to rise to $4 trillion, according to ING.
column7: The supply increase, alongside the Federal Reserve's pledge to keep monetary policy loose while economic growth and inflation rise, has contributed to rising Treasury yields. Investors will also focus on Fed Chair Jerome Powell on Tuesday, who is expected to be peppered with questions at a congressional hearing here about the potential risks from the Fed's super-easy policy including its bond buying program.
column8: Last week, the benchmark 10-year Treasury yield, hit 1.754%, a 14-month high. It traded around 1.68% on Monday.
column9: The Treasury will sell $60 billion of two-year notes on Tuesday, $61 billion of five-year notes on Wednesday and $62 billion of seven-year notes on Thursday.
column10: “I think there’s good reason for optimism for the auctions this week,” said John Canavan, lead analyst at Oxford Economics.
column11: He said Feb. 25’s $62 billion seven-year note auction, which resulted in the lowest demand ratio for that maturity on record, was an outlier and that auctions for other maturities since then have gone “quite well.”
column12: Last week’s $24 billion, 20-year bond auction saw aggressive bidding, with a bid-to-cover ratio, a gauge of demand, of 2.51 to 1, compared to February’s auction that resulted in a 2.15 to 1 ratio, the lowest since the maturity was relaunched in May 2020.
column13: Canavan also pointed to an expected uptick in foreign demand and growing flows into taxable government bond funds, citing Investment Company Institute data with continued inflows perhaps supported by taxpayers investing stimulus cash.
column14: “The investment fund demand and foreign demand, which are the two primary drivers of auctions, have largely so far kept pace with the increased auction sizes over the past year,” he said. “Even if the investment fund demand starts to plateau, that just means that while (bid-to-cover ratios) won’t be extreme, they’ll still be strong.”
column15: Zachary Griffiths, macro strategist at Wells Fargo, said while auctions of 10-year notes and 20- and 30-year bonds this month were deemed to be fairly successful, trading in the auction aftermath was lower in price.
column16: “These auctions have become liquidity events and people are taking advantage of that, but you’re still seeing some difficulty in trading on the follow through, which suggests that underlying demand is not all that sturdy,” he said.
column17: He added that even though five- and seven-year note yields are more attractive than a month ago, those auctions may be a bit more challenged than the two-year note auction, which should probably do well.

column4: Yields on longer-term JGB fall tracking U.S. Treasuries move
column5: TOKYO, March 23 (Reuters) - Yields on longer term Japanese government bonds fell, tracking U.S. Treasuries as investors bet on a faster economic recovery in the United States and higher inflation pressures.
column6: The 20-year JGB yield fell 1.5 basis points to 0.445%, while the 30-year JGB yield fell 0.5 basis point to 0.625%.
column7: The 40-year JGB yield fell 0.5 basis point to 0.670%.
column8: The 10-year JGB yield was unchanged at 0.075%, while the five-year yield rose 0.5 basis point to minus 0.095%. Benchmark 10-year JGB futures fell 0.02 point to 151.28, with a trading volume of 10,971 lots.

column4: Wall Street closes up on tech rebound; Tesla gains
column5: NEW YORK (Reuters) - Wall Street rallied on Monday as technology stocks rebounded from a recent selloff sparked by surging bond yields and Tesla jumped after a fund run by an influential investor in the electric-car maker said its shares could approach $3,000 by 2025.
column6: Tesla Inc’s 2.31% gain to $670 was the fourth-largest boost to the S&P 500 after Ark Invest, founded by star stockpicker Cathie Wood, raised the company’s price target on Friday using 34 inputs in a Monte Carlo model.
column7: Tesla traded more than 6% higher during the session before trimming gains. (Graphic: Tesla's 12-month stock performance trounces Nasdaq, )
column8: Growth stocks rose more than 1.43% while value shares slid 0.07% in a reversal of this year’s big rotation in investment portfolios.
column9: A sharp run-up in Treasury yields since mid-February has weighed on high-flying technology stocks that benefit from low yields as investors swarmed into underpriced value stocks from the mega-cap growth stocks that have fueled the past year’s rally.
column10: An easing off of 14-month highs in the 10-year U.S. Treasury note’s yield after it hit 1.754% last week has allowed tech shares to bounce back, said Tom Hayes, chairman of hedge fund Great Hill Capital LLC in New York.
column11: “It’s going to look like tech and growth is back but I think it will be much more moderate than people think,” Hayes said. “There’s a plethora of growth, growth across many sectors, and we’ve seen managers bidding those (shares) up in cyclicals and value. I think that persists over the next 18 months,” he said.
column12: The tech-heavy Nasdaq outpaced the S&P 500 and the Dow, both of which posted all-time highs last week on bets that stimulus and vaccine rollouts will likely lead to the strongest U.S. economic growth since 1983.
column13: “The technology stocks are pretty beaten down and it’s not shocking to see those rebounding a little bit from their lows,” said Jake Wujastyk, chief market analyst and founding member of TrendSpider.
column14: Kansas City Southern surged 11.1% after Canadian Pacific Railway Ltd agreed to acquire the railroad operator in a $25 billion cash-and-stock deal to create the first railway spanning the United States, Mexico and Canada.
column15: The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed up 103.23 points, or 0.32%, at 32,731.2. The S&P 500 gained 27.49 points, or 0.70%, to 3,940.59 and the Nasdaq Composite added 162.31 points, or 1.23%, to 13,377.54.
column16: Volume on U.S. exchanges was 10.91 billion shares, compared with the 14.3 billion average over the last 20 trading days.
column17: Bank stocks, which have enjoyed a rally on brightening economic prospects, dropped 2.27%.
column18: The S&P 500 tech index jumped 1.93%, while energy and financials closed down 1.01% and 1.30%, respectively.
column19: The iShares MSCI Turkey ETF sank 18.96% after President Tayyip Erdogan’s decision to oust a hawkish central bank governor sparked fears of a reversal of recent rate hikes.
column20: Declining issues outnumbered advancing ones on the NYSE by a 1.18-to-1 ratio; on Nasdaq, a 1.25-to-1 ratio favored decliners.
column21: The S&P 500 posted 12 new 52-week highs and no new lows; the Nasdaq Composite recorded 99 new highs and 30 new lows.

column4: Explainer: What rising bond yields mean for markets
column5: NEW YORK (Reuters) - Yields on U.S. Treasuries have surged to their highest level in more than a year from record lows hit in 2020, as Federal Reserve commitments to hold rates near zero for years to come encouraged investors to bet economic growth and inflation will heat up.
column6: Though yields remain low by historical standards, a rapid rise can ripple through to affect assets ranging from equities and commodities to housing prices.
column7: Here’s what’s happening:
column8: Why are yields rising?
column9: In recent months, breakthroughs in developing COVID-19 vaccines and fiscal stimulus have raised expectations the economy will bounce back. Improving risk appetite has encouraged investors to buy riskier assets such as stocks rather than bonds. Expectations of inflation have also jumped, driving bond prices lower and yields higher. Weaker demand for debt was evident in last month’s disappointing auction of seven-year U.S. Treasury notes that helped push up yields.
column10: Where do investors think yields will go next?
column11: Investors generally believe yields will climb more in 2021, though some think the Fed could move to cap a rise in yields that it views as extreme enough to threaten the economic recovery. Some analysts think this could happen if 10-year Treasury yields rise much above 2% without substantial economic improvement.
column12: What does the rise in yields mean for other assets?
column13: Higher Treasury yields have made the U.S. dollar more attractive to income-seeking investors, boosting it from three-year lows reached in January.
column14: On the other hand, the spot price for non-yielding gold is down this year after outperforming nearly all other assets last year.
column15: For stocks, rising yields are a mixed bag, slowing a rally in technology and other growth stocks as investors worry about erosion of long-cash flows for these companies. But higher yields have also lifted financial stocks and accelerated a rotation into other beaten-down sectors.
column16: How could higher Treasury yields affect individuals?
column17: Effects on individual pocketbooks can be seen most directly in the housing market. The interest rates charged on fixed-rate mortgages tend to shadow moves in Treasury yields and have already begun moving higher.
column18: Savers could start to see rates increase in high yield savings accounts again.

column4: METALS-Copper slides as dollar firms on higher U.S. yields
column5: (Updates prices)
column6: HANOI, March 19 (Reuters) - Copper prices slid on Friday as the dollar firmed on the back of rising U.S. Treasury yields, making greenback-priced metals more expensive for holders of other currencies.
column7: Three-month copper on the London Metal Exchange was down 1.7% to $8,898 a tonne by 0707 GMT, while the most-traded May copper contract on the Shanghai Futures Exchange shed 1.6% to 66,020 yuan ($10,146.93) a tonne.
column8: LME tin dropped 0.5% to $25,705 a tonne, aluminium was down 0.7% to $2,201.50 a tonne and ShFE aluminium fell 1.6% to 17,415 yuan a tonne. SHFE nickel declined 0.1% to 120,610 yuan a tonne.
column9: U.S. 10-year Treasury yields rose on Thursday above 1.75% for the first time in 14 months, pushing the dollar higher, as investors digested the U.S. Federal Reserve’s pushback against expectations of any early interest rate hikes.
column10: “The yields rising indeed brought more demand for the U.S. dollar...(but) the Fed meeting was actually very bullish for value or cyclical assets,” said a Singapore-based metal trader.
column11: “It is bullish for industrial activity and commodities because money will flow out to emerging markets. Any dip in metals is a chance to buy now.”
column12: * Cancelled warrants for LME aluminium MALSTX-TOTAL - metals earmarked for delivery rose to their highest since February 2020 at 382,325 tonnes.
column13: * China’s aluminium imports in the first two months of 2021 rose 150.7% from a year earlier, customs data showed, as overseas metal booked at favourable prices continued to flow into the world’s biggest aluminium market.
column14: * The global nickel market surplus shrank to 8,400 tonnes in January from a revised surplus of 14,700 tonnes in the previous month, data from the International Nickel Study Group showed.
column15: * For the top stories in metals and other news, click or

column4: METALS-Industrial metals fall as dollar firms on higher U.S. yields
column5: HANOI, March 19 (Reuters) - Base metal prices fell on Friday as rising U.S. Treasury yields strengthened the safe-haven dollar, making greenback-priced metals more expensive to holders of other currencies.
column6: Three-month copper on the London Metal Exchange was down 0.7% to $8,995 a tonne by 0108 GMT, while the most-traded May copper contract on the Shanghai Futures Exchange shed 0.6% to 66,740 yuan ($10,259.17) a tonne.
column7: LME nickel dropped 1.2% to $15,840 a tonne, aluminium was down 0.5% to $2,206 a tonne and ShFE aluminium fell 1.7% to 17,390 yuan a tonne. SHFE nickel declined 1.8% to 118,570 yuan a tonne.
column8: Rising Treasury yields and falling stock markets pushed the dollar higher, as investors continued to digest the U.S. Federal Reserve’s pushback against expectations of any early interest-rate hikes.
column9: The yield on the U.S. 10-year Treasury note on Thursday rose above 1.75% for the first time in 14 months.
column10: * Cancelled warrants for LME aluminium MALSTX-TOTAL - metals earmarked for delivery - rose to their highest since February 2020 at 382,325 tonnes.
column11: * China’s aluminium imports in the first two months of 2021 rose 150.7% from a year earlier, customs data showed, as overseas metal booked at favourable prices continued to flow into the world’s biggest aluminium market.
column12: * The global nickel market surplus shrank to 8,400 tonnes in January from a revised surplus of 14,700 tonnes in the previous month, data from the International Nickel Study Group showed.

column14: * Asian share markets eased as a spike in global bond yields soured sentiment toward richly priced tech stocks, while a stampede out of crowded positions in crude oil caused the sharpest setback in months.
